newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: WOLTERS KLUWER SALES BOOSTED BY CCH.
newsitem.headline: WOLTERS KLUWER SALES BOOSTED BY CCH.

text.p: Dutch publisher Wolters Kluwer NV said on Friday its sales mushroomed 47 percent to 4.32 million guilders in 1996, propelled by higher than expected growth through acquisitions.
"Even without the significant effect of the acquisition of (U.S. tax publisher) CCH early 1996, growth through acquisition exceeded our expectations," Wolters said in a statement.
It said organic growth had progressed satisfactorily, enabling it to consolidate and extend its market position in the 25 countries where it was active.
Excluding the CCH takeover, sales grew by 11 percent due to a combined effect of organic growth, acquisitions and moderately favourable exchange rates, Wolters Kluwer said.
It said CCH had also propelled operating income sharply higher. Operating income before goodwill writedowns jumped 52 percent to 927 million guilders, with CCH accounting for 45 percent of the gain.
Operating income before amortization of goodwill as a percentage of sales increased from 20.7 percent to 21.5 percent, Wolters added.
Wolters Kluwer earlier reported 1996 net profits rose to 479 million guilders from a year-earlier 452 million.
Analysts had expected the law and tax publisher to report a net profit of between 461 and 491 million guilders.
